Huck, we humans generally make a distinction between ourselves and the rest of the animal world.
 
 It is true that we belong to the animal kingdom, that we are warm-blooded mammals, but having risen somewhat in the kingdom because we're probably smarter than the other beasties, other agencies rule our behavior. We have devised an intricate code of conduct that the other beasties lack.
 
 Zoologists indicate that the roots of our code are visible in other species but we have had the advantage over other species in being able to widely communicate with each other and the ability to pool our knowledge, not to mention the ability to debate and hammer out better rules of conduct.
 
 Furthermore, there is an amazing differential in the behavior of humans. Some behavior may appear to be instinctual but. . .
 
 We are still, largely, at the mercy of our hormones but again our code of behavior may serve to overrule our hormonal impulses.
 
 We are creatures of artifice. We have created ourselves. We have the power to recreate ourselves in other ways.
 
 The other beasties seem not to care much for artifice--in truth, they are so preoccupied with seeking food and reproducing and mere survival that they have little time for such pursuits--had they even the inclination.
